data.title: The security level of markdown preview is not honored after refreshing the content
data.body:
re https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30879

I have following content in a markdown file 

```
[![Join the chat at https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net](https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net/badge.svg)](https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net) [![Build Status](https://api.travis-ci.org/rubyide/vscode-ruby.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/rubyide/vscode-ruby) [![Build status](https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/vlgs2y7tsc4xpj4c?svg=true)](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rebornix/vscode-ruby)
```

* Preview the content
* It's saying some content are not secure, none of the three image is shown
* Change the security setting to allow http
* All images are shown now. Click the title bar and the content gets refreshed.
* None of the images is shown and the alert is there again. Click on the alert, the quick pick pops up and it's saying current security level is `allow http` but it doesn't really work.

Maybe related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31837

data.title: Indent rules don't work in PHP
Markdown security settings disables svgs from Travis and Appveyor
data.body:
re https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30879
 
I have following content in a markdown file

```
[![Join the chat at https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net](https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net/badge.svg)](https://rubyide-slackin.azurewebsites.net) [![Build Status](https://api.travis-ci.org/rubyide/vscode-ruby.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/rubyide/vscode-ruby) [![Build status](https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/vlgs2y7tsc4xpj4c?svg=true)](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rebornix/vscode-ruby)
```
* Preview
* It's saying some content has been disabled and none of these svgs is shown
* Switch back to the content, the editor hints that the first svg is not secure. However the latter two are travis and appveyor, which we should allow rendering

data.title: Terminal Switcher closes on Arrow key
data.body:
While testing #31784.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:07:59.267Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open 3 terminals
2. Select `Terminal: Switch Active Terminal` from the command palette
3. <kbd>ArrowDown</kbd> to the first terminal in the switcher
4. Move keyboard focus to rename action using 2 <kbd>Tab</kbd>s. See #31835.
5. <kbd>ArrowDown</kbd> to move focus to row below
-> terminal switcher closes. It should remain open and move the selection to the row below.

data.title: Terminal Switcher:  Rename should be reachable with first tab
data.body:
While testing #31784.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:07:59.267Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open 3 terminals
2. Select `Terminal: Switch Active Terminal` from the command palette
3. <kbd>ArrowDown</kbd> to the last terminal in the switcher
4. <kbd>Tab</kbd> to rename the terminal
-> keyboard focus disappears from the input box (and seems to be nowhere). I need a second <kbd>Tab</kbd> to move the keyboard focus to the rename action in the selected row. A single <kbd>Tab</kbd> should suffice.

data.title: Auto indent doesn't play nice with Google C++ Style Guide
data.body:
The [Google C++ Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html) has a few ways of wrapping lines, these could be applies to JS/TS as well but are not that common in those languages. Here these are:

```cpp
// Wrap at the opening paren
GetModuleBaseName(process_handle, modules, process_name, 
                  sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
GetModuleBaseName(process_handle,
                  modules,
                  process_name, 
                  sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));

// Double indent to indicate wrapped line
GetModuleBaseName(process_handle,modules, process_name,
    sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
GetModuleBaseName(
    process_handle, modules, process_name, sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
GetModuleBaseName(
    process_handle,
    modules,
    process_name,
    sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
```

Both of these styles are not handled well by the auto indent logic. For example, copying this string (\n included):

```cpp

GetModuleBaseName(process_handle, modules, process_name, 
                  sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
```

Into an empty line will result in:

```cpp
GetModuleBaseName(process_handle, modules, process_name, 
  sizeof(process_name) / sizeof(TCHAR));
```

Notice the single (2) indent adjustment, forcing the user to realign the text (or press undo).

---

Since we know what the indent size is (2), perhaps a good way to accommodate this style of wrapping lines is to notice that the current line has a non-standard indentation and to not be as aggressive as a result. It gets a little complicated when you consider code copied from an external source and pasted in that may have differing rules though.

data.title: Images in markdown preview are not always reloaded when increasing security setting
data.body:
Testing #30879

- Open the suggested cat markdown preview
- Change security setting to the most permissive
- Change security setting to "Strict"
- The https cat is not visible.
- But if I open the security picker and click "Strict" again, it shows up. Or if I just close/reopen the preview

data.title: Keybindings Editor: Enter edit mode on Enter

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While testing #31784.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:07:59.267Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select `Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts` from the command palette
2. Type `switch `
3. <kbd>ArrowDown</kbd> to `Switch Terminal`
4. <kbd>Enter</kbd>
-> The row has now the keyboard focus but it should have entered edit mode directly. I still can get into edit mode by moving the keyboard focus with Shift+Tab, but it would be way more convenient to enter edit mode directly.

data.title: Test: Indent Rules
data.body:
We have indent rules for several languages and let's test against it to see if it's not expected or annoying you.

Complexity: 2

* [x] Less @Lixire anyOS
* [x] PHP @roblourens anyOS
* [x] C/CPP @roblourens anyOS
* [x] HTML @chrmarti anyOS please test embedded languages

Scenarios:
* Type, usually brackets or keywords for block
* Move Lines, moving content into a block should adjust the indentation
* Enter
* Paste. Note we only adjust the indentation of the first line and apply the offset to following lines in the pasted block.

data.title: Keybindings editor retains selection across instantiations
data.body:
While testing #31784.

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:07:59.267Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select `Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts` from the command palette
-> search box has the keyboard focus
2. Type `switch `
3. <kbd>ArrowDown</kbd> to `Switch Terminal`
4. <kbd>Enter</kbd> to set keyboard focus in this row
5. <kdb>Cmd+W</kbd> to close the editor
6. Select `Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts` from the command palette
-> the first row has the keyboard focus instead of the search field

data.title: macOS: Copying text to clipboard does not preserve tabs
data.body:
This might be an Electron problem rather than VS Code, but copying text to the clipboard does not preserve tabs. Instead, it converts the tabs to an appropriate number of non-breaking space characters.

Here is `settings.json`:

```javascript
{
    "editor.fontFamily": "'SFMono Light', Hack, Menlo, Monaco, 'Courier New', monospace",
    "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
    "editor.fontSize": 15,
"editor.renderIndentGuides": true,
    "terminal.integrated.fontSize": 14,
    "editor.insertSpaces": false,
    "editor.autoIndent": false,
    "editor.detectIndentation": false
}
```

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:22:50.650Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
angular1-code-snippets-johnpapastyle|lpe|0.1.0
guides|spy|0.8.4
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert text with tabs
2. Copy text to clipboard
3. Clipboard contents have non-breaking spaces instead of tabs

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Single-click gesture to get rid of all custom keybindings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While testing #30276.

The keybindings editor should have a simple way to reset to the out-of-the-box keybindings.

Steps to reproduce:
1. From the command palette choose `Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts`
2. Customize a key binding, save, close
3. Do something else
4. Try to undo your key binding change
-> You need to go to advanced settings to delete the blob of json.

We should have a single-click gesture to get rid of all custom keybindings.

data.title: Unexpected results when using / in include on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:16:44.254Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
git-project-manager|fel|1.3.2
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3

(1 theme extensions excluded)

---

Testing #31480

I say search in `./src` but it appears to be searching everything. Note that using include `.\src` works perfectly fine.

Single folder:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28837775-d626cb08-76a2-11e7-8574-53b188306df1.png)

Multi-root workspace:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28837862-2a30125e-76a3-11e7-93d2-8c0b1be8d8c9.png)

So there's two things here:

- Why is it searching everything when a folder literally named "./src" does not exist
- Maybe it would be best to assume `\` when `/` is used on Windows? This is what I do with links in the terminal, it's common for `/` path separators to show up on Windows. Personally I used `/` just now without even thinking about it because I jump around OS's all the time.

data.title: deleteWordLeft and deleteWordRight inconsistent on Windows
data.body:
#30276

Have 

```
 {
        "key": "ctrl+9",
        "command": "workbench.action.terminal.deleteWordLeft",
        "when": "terminalFocus"
    },

    {
        "key": "ctrl+0",
        "command": "workbench.action.terminal.deleteWordRight",
        "when": "terminalFocus"
    }
```

ctrl+9 should delete back, but inserts `^W`
ctrl+0 should delete right, but inserts `D`

data.title: Use a native node module to pull Windows shell process information
Can we present multiple search results on the same line more effectively?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:16:44.254Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
git-project-manager|fel|1.3.2
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3

(1 theme extensions excluded)

---

Testing #31480

(I may have created an issue similar to this before)

It's always annoyed me the same line shows up multiple times in the search results, even when the line is really small and would fit in the viewlet just fine. Consider this example where the first line is complete:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28835792-7c2ecd1e-769b-11e7-8283-d6ec46cb9ece.png)

This would be better ideal in this case (I modified the DOM):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28835931-f4940c74-769b-11e7-87ef-17e9044ab191.png)

I understand the argument against this, where really long lines cannot show multiple results like this. Maybe we can size the search results to suit the width of the search viewlet, re-laying out the results when the viewlet is resized?

---

Here's the extreme case illustrating the issue:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/28836054-59be6df6-769c-11e7-8414-44cb2c240cd1.png)

data.title: VSCode reporting Typescript errors incorrectly when opened from a subdirectory from tsconfig
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a folder structure where the TS files are in a subdirectory from the location of tsconfig.json
2. Open the directory with the TS files in VSCode.
3. Symbols from unopened files are not recognized even though running tsc works fine as does opening the root folder in VSCode.

Example repo: https://github.com/jamirvin/VSCodeBug

One strange thing I've noticed is that if you change the version number in the Typescript directory's package.json to be lower than 2.3 it works, regardless of the actual Typescript version being used. 

Demo:
![vscode_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14207652/28834670-e950f092-76b0-11e7-827d-573eba67c1a9.gif)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Cannot read error message because error popup too small.
data.body:
When building code that might fail for any number of reasons I am commonly unable to even read the error message that pops up because the window only shows part of the first line. The error does not appears in the Problems, Output or Debug panes.

Here I am attempting to execute a Typescript project.

![unreadableerror](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18445931/28834685-e28451ee-76da-11e7-8765-5f4d869c36c0.png)

Here's how I created the project:

Create a directory and open VSCode there.

Press F1, enter "Debug: Open launch.json" and when prompted select environment node.js. This will generate a launch.json file configured for node.js.

Press CTRL+' to open the command prompt. Enter "tsc --init" this will generate a tsconfig.json file.
NOTE: tsc must be version 1.6 or greater. Check with "tsc -v", upgrade with "npm install -g typescript".

In tsconfig.json uncomment "sourcemap": "true"
In tsconfig.json uncomment "outdir" and set to "./output".

Press CTRL+SHIFT+B to build, select nodejs build environment.

Press F5 to execute. Error message appears that cannot be read.


- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.3
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.7
auto-close-tag|for|0.4.2
csharp|ms-|1.10.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.4
vscode-css-peek|pra|1.2.4
html-css-class-completion|Zig|1.7.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)

data.title: Emmet 2.0: wrap individual lines with abbreviation that has implicit repeater is broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (f39385b8326671dc6389f21f8c2e2f6afdb352a1, 2017-08-01T05:07:59.267Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- ng-template|Ang|0.1.4 code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.2 sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0 html-snippets|abu|0.1.0 Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2 project-manager|ale|0.18.1 path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2 vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11 tslint|eg2|0.17.0 auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14 Angular2|joh|2.4.0 ecdc|mit|0.10.3 HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3 vscode-autoprefixer|mrm|2.1.1 vscode-stylefmt|mrm|2.5.0 angular2-inline|nat|0.0.17 stylelint|shi|0.28.0 change-case|wma|1.0.0 (4 theme extensions excluded) --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. create a bunch of lines that you want to be a bulleted list, or paste a bulleted text list like I did, in this format: ```` lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum ```` 2. select the block and use the "Emmet: Wrap with abbreviation" command 3. Issue the command `ul>li*|t` 4. you get an error: ```` Failed to expand abbreviation e.doShow @ /Applications/Visual Studio Code - Insiders.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:28 ```` This command, in Emmet 1.0, would wrap the lines with a list and remove the bullets, as in ````
  • lorem ipsum
  • lorem ipsum
  • lorem ipsum
````

data.title: F12 to jump to definition when a webpack context is set up blocks jumping to definition
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
bracket-pair-colorizer|Coe|0.10.7
vscode-markdownlint|Dav|0.10.0
jshint|dba|0.10.15
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3
vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4
vscode-language-babel|mgm|0.0.7
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
autoimport|ste|1.2.2
react-redux-es6-snippets|tim|2.1.0
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
markdown-all-in-one|yzh|0.8.1
html-css-class-completion|Zig|1.8.0



---

This may well have something to do with the set up of my project.

If I set up a context configuration in webpack and remove relative ../../ parts of imports I find I cannot navigate to definitions via the gift of the F12 button.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new project
2. Create a folder called src, then in that folder create a folder called components. In this folder create a file in it with a basic "hello world" component.
3. Create another file which imports that component, but make sure that the import name is 'components/HelloWorld'
4. Set up a webpack.config file to have context set to the src folder: `context: path.join(__dirname, './src'),`
5. Build the project - it will build and it will run, but when you try to navigate to the code via the F12 button, an "No definition found for <last part of file path>" error is shown.

Error shown
![f12 bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3604276/28831484-950b531c-76d1-11e7-9b40-7b61fe6c6384.png)

Actions folder (files does exist in that location)
![actionsfolder](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3604276/28831493-99fda348-76d1-11e7-96be-a1c21c4333ce.PNG)

Webpack context section
![projectcontext](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3604276/28831654-12a92376-76d2-11e7-92e7-b22daa348459.PNG)


Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Better support of cursor movement keybinding.
data.body:
I'm an emacs-style keybinding user, and I'm willing to use emacs-style cursor movement shortcut everywhere in VSCode.
Though this goal can be achieved in most case, there's still some trouble:
- In popup input window like findWidget and renameWidget, there's no way to modify the cursor movment key(.e.g C-b/f to move cursor left/right).
- In referenceSearch widget, there's no way to make C-p/n to focusUp/focusDown through the result list in the right side, I have to use arrow key to do that.

I believe I've tried every available options, please tell me if I missed anything.
Thanks!

data.title: VSCode 1.15 on macOS: Scroll to Top and Scroll to Bottom not working
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15 (1.15)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Code
2. Open any file
3. Press Cmd + Home, the Scroll to Top default keyboard shortcut. Observe that nothing happens.
4. Press Cmd + End, the Scroll to Bottom default keyboard shortcut. Observe that nothing happens.

I also tried binding Ctrl + Home to Scroll to Top and Ctrl + End to Scroll to Bottom. Neither of those bound shortcuts worked.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Closing tabs with middle-mouse-click propagates through save confirmation popup
data.body:
Most of the time I have one or more unsaved "Untitled" files open for quick notes, etc. When I am now going on a streak of middle-clicking all tabs to close them, I often hit the middle mouse button on the unsaved file multiple times, which results in the "Do you want to save the changes ..." popup appearing multiple times for the same file.

---

How to reproduce:

* Open up a new file, add some text but don't save it
* Click the middle mouse button multiple times on the tab to close it
* The popup appears asking you if you want to save "Untitled-1".
    * Click "Cancel"
* The popup appears again and again (=> the amount of time you've middle-clicked the tab).

This can also be reproduced in the "Open Editors" pane to the left.

Also, the actions are queued - trying to close a second (saved) file while the dialog is shown closes the saved file correctly after all the dialogs are dismissed.

---

- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions (all disabled):
